Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 11:19AM - edited Jul 23, 2011 11:20AM by Suze35 There has been one (maybe two) studies done on diet and exercise - here is a link to a summary of the WINS study: http://www.cancer.gov/newscenter/pressreleases/2006/winsbreaststudy ER/PR+ women showed a 20% overall reduction in recurrence when they lowered their fat intake and upped exercise.  So if you have let's say a 20% chance of recurrence, diet and exercise can theoretically lower that to 16%.  The benefit is more obvious for triple negative breast cancers, with recurrence rates dropping by as much as 40+%.  More studies need to be done obviously. For the OP - do you have any other information about your cancer?  What is the proliferation rate (Ki-67)?  How big is the tumor actually?  I know it says 1cm in your stats, but is it closer to 2 cm?  Size also plays a role in possible recurrence.  How much of it was DCIS?  Did they identify lymphovascular invasion (different from positive lymph nodes).  It is Grade 3, and those cancers are at greater risk for metastisizing.  They also tend to respond better to chemo.  A bit of a quandry.  I would agree that age and overall health should also be taken into consideration. Would your doctors be willing to offer Taxol rather than Taxotere? It has a decreased incidence of neuropathy, although the chance is still there.  Taxol can be given weekly as well to deal with this. In the end, this is a decision you have to be comfortable with, as well as your family.  Do they have any opinions?  I hate it when doctors don't give you their clear opinions, it is frustrating. Good luck with your decision!

Posts.Content: Suze35 wrote: Hello to any of you reading this note. I am not Susan, but one of her closest friends. She asked me months ago if, when the time came, I would be willing to let her many friends on line know what happened. Sadly that day has arrived. Susan passed away at home this morning - as she had requested - with her husband and mother beside her. Her three beautiful children were away at school, which was probably for the best. She was only 42 yrs old and four days shy of the 18 mth anniversary of her discovery of the cancer. She wanted you all to know what happened to her as these boards and your notes gave her so much support and strength as she battled against this disease. She told me to tell you that she will miss you all and that you must not give up hope. For her, this cancer was like a runaway train - nothing was going to stop it. But that may not be the case for many of you reading this, and I know she wouldn't want any of you to feel disheartened. Even with such an aggressive cancer, Susan felt that the new discoveries might have been able to help her - if only she had developed the disease a little bit later. So don't give up the fight. We will, as her friends and family, continue her legacy by helping to care for her three young children. If you would like to leave a comment or remembrance of Susan, she requested that I save and print them for her children to read when they get older. I am sorry to have such sad news to pass on, but pray that for many of you there will be a happier outcome. - Kim Shapiro Original dx Stage IIIa TN 9/2010 Dx 9/19/2011, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 8/12 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 07:12PM Suze35 wrote: Solange - I actually did Taxol and Carboplatin, so I can't speak to the Gemzar regimen, but I have heard that the hardest part of it is low blood counts and fatigue. I know Carbo dumped my numbers to the point of needing Neupogen shots the last five weeks, and I did weekly doses. Being Grade 2, it would make sense that you didn't respond as well to the chemo (slower growing tumor). Has your doctor computed your Residual Cancer Burden? It looks at things like residual cellularity, leftover DCIS vs. invasive components, and yes, remaining nodes. Many oncologists wouldn't recommend more chemo, because there are not many studies backing up its effectiveness. Those studies, however, are now starting. The good things you are ER+, which means AIs will help reduce your risk. I suggest a second opinion if you haven't had one yet, at a large cancer center or university if possible. Maybe see if there are any trials that suit you as well? It is a tough decision as to whether or not to go for more chemo. I was TN, so I chose to throw everything I could at it. I wish you the best in your decision.

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2011 02:30PM Suze35 wrote: I'm on day 5 of my second week, and definitely feeling more effects from the Halaven.  I am more prone to vomiting, without much warning, but the worst is the heartburn, ugh.  I wake up in the middle of the night with it, and also the morning.  I've been using Zantac, but think I'll have to go to Prilosec.  I also have had to start taking Ativan for the mild nausea.  Thankfully my off week is coming... I think I was hoping this drug would be like Abraxane was for me, with almost no SEs.  Ah well, it is chemo afterall, and if it beats back the cancer for awhile, I'll take it. I haven't had to have any Neulasta or Neupogen, but it is just my first cycle.  But my numbers are holding up well, so I'm hoping I can hold off on the shots for a bit. Hope everyone else is tolerating the Halaven well! Susan
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Title: BeckyOD sincitydealer Lena

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 03:18PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 10:50AM by Suze35 ETA - I still have quite a bit of bruising around my biopsy site and the MRI tech said yesterday that it would probably still show some inflammation from the biopsy over a week later.  I know what you mean about psychosomatic, but I think your body is still healing and absorbing the blood from the bruising, which can cause a little discomfort.  DivaJMusic - I'm so sorry you are here also.  I was diagnosed a week and a half ago, and this initial part is so terrifying, it is hard to wrap your brain around it.  I ended up getting a prescription for Ativan - I use it mainly at night, as it helps me sleep and I don't dream.  When I feel the anxiety creep in during the day, I sometimes take 1/2 a tablet, but not that often.  I am also young(ish) at 41, with no known history, and 3 beautiful kids. My stats at the bottom are a little misleading - I actually have TWO lumps (around 1" each), four confirmed nodes (but my onc believes they are in the breast tissue and are not "lumping" together, hence Stage IIb), and we are 75% sure it is triple negative.  Still waiting on the FISH for the HER2neu, as it was initially HER2neu++. I am starting my chemotherapy on Thursday - 2 weeks from the day that I found my lump - and I think that is saving my sanity.  Push for quick treatment - but responsible treatment - if possible.  The thought that in just a few days I will actually be DOING something has given me purpose. I no longer break down at the sight of my kids, and my wonderful oncologist has given me hope that I'll live to see them grown with babies of their own.  Make sure you and your doctors are on the same page - even if it is just emotionally.  I could not handle a completely clinical doctor, I need someone to be a bit compassionate and reassuring. I have found that reading the threads here is very inspiring - these women are survivors, at any stage, and it helps me to keep my life in perspective.  I don't go much beyond that anymore.  I know what I have, roughly what stage, and what my treatment will be.  Now I just want to read about how these women have overcome everything I'm about to go through.  You will find strength in their stories too, I have no doubt. I wish you luck and good healh - this is treatable!  That was my BIGGEST fear - that someone would say "sorry, too late to treat you."  Even now I'm a little afraid of my second opinion meeting tomorrow, lol.  But IT IS TREATABLE!!
Posts.Title: tough weekend DivaJMusic chrissyc

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 10:48PM Suze35 wrote: Joining the Halaven group! I just had my first dose today, I liked that there were no premeds, and it was a quick, 5 minute infusion. If I don't see a response to Halaven, I don't have a ton of options, so fingers crossed.

My numbers were just at the borderline for a full dose, so my doctor went ahead and gave me one, figuring we can back off a bit next time if need be. I'm hoping to avoid neuropathy - I never had it with any of the taxanes. I hope the Halaven treats you well!

Karen - I am already on Decadron (trying to wean) so I don't even have to wait for that, or tummy meds. That quick push is definitely nice. Here's hoping it works *raises alcoholic beverage in salud!*. And get some rest, you lucky woman :).
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 06:00PM Suze35 wrote: I'm on day 5, and I'd have to say my worst was day 3.  I actually vomited once, but didn't really feel nauseated - it just came over me quickly, then passed.  I do have that disconnected feeling also - which I hate - and the steroids I'm on don't help that.  I'm really, really, REALLY tired - like, fall asleep standing at the kitchen counter tired.  I also have that metallic/off taste - food tastes so bland, I end up salting the heck out of it, which then bloats me up even more.  But, I can tell I'm on the upswing because I've been having better mornings.  I'm not sure I'll be able to get my Wednesday dose - my numbers were borderline for my last dose (I had to be at 100, and was at 94 for one of them, can't remember what exactly needed to be at 100).  I may have to wait a few days, which is fine. I think it might be helping though - I was only able to sleep on my left side due to my shortness of breath issues, but now I can sleep on both sides comfortably.  My bloating has also stablilized, and my tummy is softer, not hard as a rock.  I'll take it! Marybe - AC really kicked my butt the first time around, but I was in curative mode at that point so they were hitting me hard.  I remember losing my hair by week 3 on that one.  I was mostly tired and nauseas - it really hit my WBCs hard, so the Neulasta was very helpful.  I hope you continue to do well with the red devil - it is a very good drug when you can tolerate it. If Halaven brings me a visit from the Stable Boy, I'll take whatever it dishes out! Susan
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 05:29PM Suze35 wrote: Karen - thanks for the suggestion on Protonix - I'll have to give that a try!  So far, if I take the Zantac twice a day, I do okay.  I have a feeling though it will only get worse, as heartburn was my one really bad SE the first time I did chemo.  So I'm sure I will need something different down the road. I'm definitely on my upswing, so days 3-5 will be the baddies it looks like.  But I was still functional, so I'll take that.  My cough is showing signs of improvement, which is great!  I don't have to take as much morphine (it suppresses my cough), so I'm not as tired.  My doctor also gave me Ritalin, which has helped with my energy levels.  Never thought I'd be on that, lol! eag - I use Ativan for nausea in small doses - 0.5 mg.  I also use it to help sleep at night (1 mg).  So either way works.  I find that if I put the tablet under my tongue, it works faster for the nausea. I'm getting an extra 2 days off on my "off week" because we are out of town for Christmas, so I'm happy I'll be feeling my best for the holiday.  I hope everyone is doing well, and that Halaven is kicking butt!  I know my MO loves this drug, and thinks it will buy me a good chunk of time.  I won't be getting any scans soon - we will go by my tumor markers and SEs for now - but I'm feeling pretty positive. Susan

Posts.Content: Suze35 wrote: In the past day, I've received a lot of messages from people interested in somehow memorializing Susan's life.  Today I created a fundraising memory page on the American Cancer Society website in Susan's honor. The link to the page is http://main.acsevents.org/site/TR/Events/MosaicofHope?pg=fund&fr_id=9910&pxfid=1146572 On the page you can see a photo of Susan and leave a message for her family or a donation or both. I have been deeply touched by what you all have written here about Susan.  I knew the Susan who was a fellow mom and great friend - you knew a Susan who was a fighter against a deadly disease.  Whether you choose to use the memory page or not, I do feel there is no memorial more suited to Susan's life than the fact that she touched so many of yours.  Thanks again, Kim Shapiro  Edited by Mods to make the link hot. Posts.Title: Suze35 Memory Page Suze35 cindoe

Posts.Content: Suze35 wrote: The clinical trial I've been waiting for has FINALLY opened, and I'll be starting treatment next week, the 13th most likely.  Not a moment too soon - I've been having terrible back pain, an MRI today showed a slipped disc and bony lesions, but no impending fracture or spinal cord problems, just lots of pain.  My doctor said it was unlikely to be CSF involvement, as that usually presents with more neurological problems, which I don't have.  But of course, I still worry.  Still, onwards and upwards!! Unfortunately, my PET report was worse than my doctors reported - tons of node involvement from neck to pelvis, several liver spots, and many bones.  I should have gotten the report myself two weeks ago, but I was putting my head in the sand.  I won't do that again!!  So I'm hoping this treatment buys me some time.  If not, well, on to the next, right?? Original dx Stage IIIa TN 9/2010 Dx 9/19/2011, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 8/12 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Finally - A Treatment Date!! Suze35 cookie97

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 10:24PM Suze35 wrote: Thank you for the well wishes, it does mean a lot to me. Helmie - I'll be scanned every 8 weeks, or as symptoms allow, so if I'm not seeing improvement in my back and cough, my doctor will probably scan after the first round. PJB - I am doing a TNBC Abraxane trial with/without Tigazumtab (sp), which is a biologic agent that targets the death receptor on tumor cells. It is one of the few trials aimed at TNBC, and is opening up at all the major cancer centers. It is randomized 2:1, but if you have progression on just chemo,they switch you over. They are having some good results, so I'm hopeful, but realistic. I can always go to traditional chemos, but only have one shot at this trial, so it was worth the wait I hope! It was actually funded by Komen!
Posts.Title: Finally - A Treatment Date!! Suze35 cookie97

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 10:33PM Suze35 wrote: Susan - it just opened at Dana Farber today, so I luckily don't have to travel. They want me signed up quick, I guess there are waiting lists at other centers trying to get access! My MO thinks it will be filled in a week, they have 60 slots. Crazy!

Posts.Title: Beautiful Saturday CoolBreeze Gtiger

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 03:44PM Suze35 wrote: Mammo failed me here as well.  Clear in April, two 4cm tumors in September.  Mine were grade 3, and I have very dense breasts, so it is likely they were there, small, and not detectable.  What bothers me is that when I got my "all clear" in April, it basically said just that.  But when I got the actual report in September, it clearly stated that due to dense breast tissue, self exam should be reinforced to the patient.  No one ever said a word about that to me.  I did do self exams, but only every few months as I had no history in my family. This is why I'm getting a BMX.  With TN and dense breasts, I will never trust mammos again.
Posts.Title: How could I go for yearly mammos and end up with a 6.5cm tumour? Cat123 scuttlers

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 02:37PM Suze35 wrote: I cross stitch, bake/cook, "window shop" on the Internet (and occasionally buy!). The cross stitching are gifts for my loved ones, so I make sure to do intricate projects that I enjoy, but also that I'm fairly sure I can finish. I've also been putting photo books together through Snapfish, which I thought would be hard for me but I'm finding it enjoyable. When I'm up for it, on chemo days DH and I pick a restaurant we've never tried and do lunch dates. We have planned short trips every two months, being flexible. We are lucky to live in the NE, so we have some nice options. When all else fails, I watch crappy tv - competitive cooking shows are my favorites - and really bad sitcoms. Thank you for this topic. It helps to read such great suggestions!

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 08:06AM Suze35 wrote: I'm not quite Stage IV, but I'm very close, so I thought I'd give you my insight. For my first-line treatment, I responded okay to AC, a 50% reduction.  When I switched to Taxol (I also had Carbo with it), I initially had a great response, but then the cancer became resistant.  After surgery, I ended up with two supraclavicular nodes, so I started Xeloda with Avastin after radiation to see if we could at least buy some time. I don't think the Xeloda is working, as I believe I'm feeling some activity back in the nodes.  Not sure what the next step is - I have a PET soon to see if it is still just in the nodes, and if it is back, we'll switch up I'm sure. My best to you.
Posts.Title: TNs who did not respond to ACT? jloon jenn3

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 04:25AM Suze35 wrote: I am new to Stage IV, but have been on some sort of treatment since my initial diagnosis a year ago, and have 3 small kids myself.  I have no great words of wisdom, as this is often my biggest regret with this disease - having to change how I do things with my kids.  I am lucky in that my mom is here (and isn't going anywhere), and my kids adore her.  She has taken on the "mom" stuff - gets them ready for school, helps them with homework, feeds them, etc.  It is hard to watch her do that stuff - that is MY job, and it about kills me. The trade-off is that I have been able to save my energy for the "fun" things.  It isn't ideal, no way.  But I think susan is on to something - pick our battles.  What are the things I want to do most with them, and how can I accomplish that? I agree with Bruburn - you have wonderfully expressed all I've been feeling.  Cancer takes so much from us, it is beyond cruel that this is part of it. Hugs and thoughts for you.
Posts.Title: Missing the mom I used to be LivingIt 40-years-old-now

Posts.Content: Suze35 wrote: I feel like I am just getting hit with the all the bad news, and with each day, keep adjusting what I am hoping for.  But it has to end, right? I met with the surgeon today - not sure why, because I'm pretty clearly going to get chemo first - but she gave me my full path report today. I knew about the IDC, but found out all four nodes tested were pretty darn positive.  Also showing lymphovascular invasion in both tumors.  Now, I know this kind of goes hand-in-hand, but still a blow.  And I would put money on having more nodes being involved, just not swollen. I still don't know about hormone receptivity, but I wouldn't be surprised if I end up triple negative given how freaking aggressive this tumor appears to be.  It is designed to kill me. I did a chest x-ray today along with a blood test to check WBCs and liver function.  Will have a breast MRI in a few days, and will be meeting with the Onc soon - probably within a week.  So at this point, all I am hoping for is no mets.  No Stage IV.  Even though I know Stage IV is manageable and can still offer me a lot of time...I just feel the spirit draining with each new report.  I can fight Stage III.  And according to the doctor, if my nodes aren't stuck together and tangled, I might even be a Stage IIb.  Not likely, but... How do I keep myself up when I keep getting hit?  I just can't catch a breath... Original dx Stage IIIa TN 9/2010 Dx 9/19/2011, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 8/12 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

I hate this disease, and TN holds a special spot of hate - if I thought the devil existed, it would be cancer. I know there is a tacked thread at the top of the board for brain mets, you should be able to find lots of info and fellow women going through WBR real-time with you. I will keep you in my thoughts that WBR knocks this stuff out and you are able to move forward with few SEs. I mentally prepare myself for this dx every day, knowing it is the way of TN, but nothing truly prepares you for this news. Hang in there. Hugs and love. Susan
Posts.Title: It has spead to my brain...... jenn3 lwd

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2011 05:34PM Suze35 wrote: I did a consult at MGH with my initial diagnosis, and am participating in a trial at Dana Farber now with my Stage IV diagnosis. I know you aren't as concerned about your surgeon, but I do think it is important.  If you have to have lymph nodes removed, or want skin sparing, etc., their skill is very important.  I chose Dr. Michelle Gadd at MGH because she is a breast surgeon with 20+ years of experience, and helped to pioneer the SNB.  I had a lot of nodes removed - two surgeries - and I credit her skill with my good surgical outcome - very little LE and an easy, quick recovery.  So while it is true you will be spending more time with your MO, be sure you are happy with your BS also. The MO at MGH offered me the same regimen as a more local doctor, so I chose my local doctor.  In the end, the local MO did quite a bit for me outside standard of care, and I'm not sure that would have happened at MGH. Dana Farber has a fantastic reputation, and so far has been good.  I had a lot of administrative snafus when starting the clinical trial, mess ups with appointments, tests that I needed, etc.  But as far as the MO is concerned, I am extremely happy with her.  She is young, very active in her research, and very well prepared.  Being Stage IV, I want someone on the top of their game, and I feel I have that.  Their infusion center is very nice, and everything is very central so parking is easy.  I can get my labs, eat at their cafeteria, and get my treatment, all in the same building. I would recommend you do a second/third opinion with each place.  You may find, like I did, that separating out your treatment is the best option.  I do think both factilities are top notch. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Dana Farber vs MGH? TectonicShift Lulu22

My MO has also said that she is excited about Halaven, so there are more chemos to try! Thinking of you.

Posts.Title: Starting Navelbine Wednesday and question about veins CoolBreeze Lilah

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 06:06AM - edited Oct 21, 2011 06:09AM by Suze35 It looks like this might be the study your mother is looking at:  http://www.clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01033032?term=amrubicin&recr=Open&no_unk=Y&rank=1 It isn't specifically for TN, but we are eligible for it given the parameters.  The drug appears to act similar to Doxirubicin, but isn't as hard on the heart.  Did you mother have AC during her first round of treatment in 2000?  If so, it would appear to have been pretty effective, as 9 years is a long time out for a TN recurrence.  Your mom's doctor may be thinking it is a good choice to try something similar again for this reason. From my personal perspective - the "traditional" drugs are always there.  But there are many clinical trials right now that combine these with other agents, and being TN, I think that these extra agents offer us the best hope for better outcomes.  I am currently in a trial myself, and if/when this one fails, I will be looking for another one if possible.  Best wishes to your mother.  ETA - I find this VERY helpful here, as I am TN and am always looking for new clinical studies. Coolbreeze - this board states it is available for both patients and caregivers as a source of information and support.  I don't see how it is inappropriate for her to be posting here?
Posts.Title: My Mom is on to a new trial km4candles EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 06:23AM Suze35 wrote: Being TN, 9 months on a non-chemo drug is actually a good run, even though I know that is hard to hear.  Your mom still has the full arsenal of chemos in her closet to fight, and it sounds like she is pretty responsive to chemo.  This is very hopeful. If you are interested in other clinical trials for your mother, this is the one I am doing: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01307891?term=death+receptor+5+uab&rank=1 It is strictly for TN, and has been showing some promise.  Abraxane can really be a work-horse, and the SEs aren't as bad as Taxol.  I am on the chemo-only arm for now, but when/if I progress, I will have the experimental agent added on. It might not be a bad idea for your mom to bring up the idea of other options to her doctor, because then he may provide her with a sound rationale.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 07:31PM Suze35 wrote: Finding the stamina to check in... I was dx Stage IV, triple negative, at the end of September, after a year-long battle just trying to keep it localized. Unfortunately my cancer is fairly chemo-resistant, and after some response to my initial AC treatment, Taxol, Carboplatin, Xeloda and Abraxane (with the experimental drug Tigatzumab) all failed. I have mets in my liver, lungs, bones, abdomen, and nodes. I started on Eribulin today, we are hoping that maybe I can get some relief from my symptoms, and a little time. I still remain hopeful that we will find something that can help for a bit, and I do still have other choices. But I'm realistic as well, so I'm doing my best to live in the moment and enjoy each day. It is hard to do when you are bloated like a pregnant woman and hacking up a lung! - so goooo Halaven! clarrissa - I waited 3 weeks between dx and the start of treatment, but I was waiting for a clinical trial to start.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 06:42PM Suze35 wrote: I think ressie has it right - consistency is key, in many cases.  My old MO used PET/CT scans mostly, and they worked for me.  I had just a CT in June that didn't show anything, but my PET in late September did.  Could be nothing was there - I have an aggressive cancer - but also could be the plain CT didn't catch it.  It will be interesting to see, as my new MO uses CT scans to monitor. Like you, I disagree that knowing about the liver is unimportant.  While it will show up down the road more obviously if treatments stop working, I would MUCH rather be prepared for that than having it sprung on me. I wish you luck getting the scans you want.

I am very pleased so far with the care coordinator and the medical staff.  I don't know what I would do without her, she is gathering my records for me, scheduling my appointments, and is just there to talk.  She is an 8-year survivor, and assured me that in all her years doing her job, she has lost VERY few patients.  I certainly won't be adding to that number! I'll be on these boards for the long haul, first to gather as much information as possible, and then to offer hope to newcomers - far too many newcomers :-(. Thank you all!
Posts.Title: Update: Unfortunately New Suze35 CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 11:28AM Suze35 wrote: I hope it is okay to add my input. I've changed my diet quite a bit since diagnosis, and the one thing I've learned is that the best way to stick to those changes is to make sure you ENJOY them.  I don't think diet and supplements can cure cancer in any way, but I do think they can help improve your health which helps you deal with treatments and recovery better.  So have your mom keep the chocolate and occasional wine, but maybe make changes where she can. For example, I eat oatmeal every morning with blueberries and soymilk.  This is supposed to be very good for me, but I really enjoy it!  I've tried avoiding animal protein except fish, but it got boring fast, so I've added lean meats back in.  I've replaced any white flour products with wheat and whole grains, but I like them, so no big deal for me.  I love wine, but have switched to red.  So see what your mom is up to doing, and go from there! And I really recommend Dr. Servan-Schreiber's book - easy to read, doesn't promote EXTREME changes, and is very uplifting.  His dietary suggestions really make sense. Best to you both.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2011 07:22PM Suze35 wrote: Hi, I'm also TN, but have liver, bone, and node mets. It is a tough dx no matter how you slice it, as we are more limited in our treatment options. The good news is there are still quite a few of those! It appears you've gone 5+ years since your initial dx, which is great - that shows you had a pretty good response to chemo the first time, and that usually indicates you will again. Hang in there, the waiting for treatment is the hardest part! I am currently doing a clinical trial of Abraxane and Tigatzumab (sp), which you might want to ask your doctor about - I don't know if it is working for me, but the early results are promising, and it is one of the few targeted drugs in trial for TN right now. There are also several trials with platins and taxanes. If you go the more traditional route, the chemos are more gently administered so QOL is maintained as best as possible. I really like www.tnbcfoundation.org, although it can initially be tough to read. However, the people there are amazing, and they tirelessly research new things for us. I'm so sorry you are here, but there is still a lot of hope. Hugs.

Posts.Title: Anyone do Neoadjuvant AND Adjuvant chemo? NannaBaby anna4969

Posts.Content: Suze35 wrote: Hello everyone. I just received my preliminary diagnosis yesterday, and it has been so darn fast that I am still processing.  I am a 41 yo mother of 3 children, nine, six and three.  I have zero history of BC in my family - in fact no cancer at all!  I had a totally clear mammogram on April 20 2010.  The radiology doctor just kept repeating "it was clear" like he couldn't believe it.  This past Thursday, when I was showering I found a lump in my upper left breast, a few inches below my armpit.  My blood went cold.  I also felt some enlarged nodes. Yesterday AM I saw my GYN who immediately sent me for a sonogram.  The doctor then immediately did the biopsy.  I have two tumors next to each other, each about 2.5 cm.  He did a suction assisted cone on one, and a regular cone on the other.  He aspirated 4 nodes - which was actually one less than he had originally thought, so that was good.  I will have the path results Monday afternoon most likely. Due to the extremely rapid growth of this tumor, I am going forward believing this is HER2+, but have been reading up on EVERYTHING.  I also assume I will be at the very least Stage IIB, and more likely early Stage IIIA. I have a few questions that I know will be answered by doctors at some point, but I could really use some feedback if at all possible! 1) Given the extreme aggressiveness of these tumors, how quickly can I expect to start any sort of treatment? 2) It doesn't appear to be inflammatory or lobular - there are clear tumors, with clear edges.  Are there any other types of aggressive tumors that are not HER2+? 3) Does having two mediumish tumors change the staging in any way? 4) Do swollen glands always indicate involvement of that specific gland?  I.e. with 4 swollen glands, can I assume I am positive for 4 or could that go down? 5) Will I see a surgeon or oncologist first?  Or will that depend on surgery vs. chemo first? Needless to say I am gobsmacked.  This came completely out of left field.  I have had pretty strong premenstrual symptoms for the past 6-8 months, and I just can't help but feel that is related - surges of hormones making these suckers grow.  I am feeling very positive having read so many great outcomes here.  It has absolutely cheered me up.  I am generally a pragmatic, upbeat person, and this has served me well.  The doctor doing the biopsy commented several times on how calm I was, given how fast this has gone. I know I can only post 5 times a day, so I will return later to comment.  Thank you! Original dx Stage IIIa TN 9/2010 Dx 9/19/2011, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 8/12 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2011 08:17PM Suze35 wrote: CoolBreeze, with respect, how is a caregiver posting a "blow-by-blow" any different than one of our sisters posting about their own experiences? I admit reading about what is likely to come scares me, but it has also informed me in so many ways. I hope that if one of my family members is in need of support and advice, they can come and ask direct and honest questions, and be welcomed with open arms. I can understand your intentions, as there are often what I think of as "drive-by" posts from those who never return. But I hate to think of even one family member in need of support being turned away. I think this specific board offers a resource that is invaluable for people living with Stage IV in many different ways.
Posts.Title: Caregiver for my mom lleddick thats-life-

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 09:49AM Suze35 wrote:
Posts.Title: Sunshine after the storm cmhartley Honeybear

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2010 09:14AM Suze35 wrote: Thank you all so VERY much - yes, you are all right and I am jumping way too far ahead of myself.  It has come about so quickly, and my first reaction is to do everything I can to understand what is going on.  Unfortunately, there is little to understand in this for the moment. I will be going through Dartmouth-Hitchcock in New Hampshire, but I live close enough to Boston if I am not comfortable with my care to go there.  I have heard excellent things about DH, and a friend of mine who is two years out from diagnosis had a fantastic experience.  Another aquaintance also did very well with DH.  I will be talking with their "breast coordinator" tomorrow AM and she will help me coordinate my care throughout this entire process.  I'll have my initial labs back tomorrow evening or Tuesday AM. I am heartened by how quickly my biopsy took place - the doctor wasn't playing around!  That bodes well I think for getting the ball moving downhill fast. I really appreciate the reassurances regarding the clear mammogram.  I have extremely dense breasts to the point that it was noted on my mammo "which markedly limits mammographic sensitivity."  They never told me this at the time (just got the report Friday), nor did they "emphasize the importance of self breast exams" as they suggested.  Thank heavens I do them anyway! When the doctor performed the biopsy, he put a small chip in each tumor to mark them, and did another mammo to place them.  I plan on getting a copy of that film because I'm curious to see if the tumors are clearly defined.  Just curiousity I guess. Twinmom77 - I am thankful to hear your nodes were negative, even though enlarged.  I haven't found very much info on that other than enlarged = involved.  The doctor at first thought there were five, but dropped it to four, which he seemed pretty relieved to do. I am feeling as good as I can, and have ZERO intention of letting this thing beat me.  I have three beautiful reasons to stick around for every second of their lives, and I will do it.
Posts.Title: Unfortunately New Suze35 lago

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 03:38PM Suze35 wrote: buttercup - they seemed to indicate they would only see me if I was between treatments, they didn't want me on anything when I came for a consult.  If I could go in while on chemo, I'd definitely do that!  I am lucky that my care has been limited to a few places, so getting them records shouldn't be TOO stressful.  susan - thank you for the info, I will definitely PM her.  I looked around for that trial and couldn't find anything (something similar but not open until January) so I am very curious about it! Jenn - thank you so much for the feedback.  This is sort of how I feel - I'm not sure MDA will offer me anything different from my MO or Dana Farber.  I'm going to start with DF tomorrow, and see where that goes.  I can always go there down the road if need be.  I hope your new treatment is doing great things for you!
